questions.text: Which of the following does not drain into azygos vein :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Left Superior Intercostal Vein The left superior intercostal vein does not drain into the azygos vein. Instead, it typically drains into the left brachiocephalic vein. This vein collects blood from the left upper thoracic region, including the left upper intercostal veins, and it does not flow directly into the azygos vein, which primarily receives drainage from the right side. Therefore, option (C) is correct. Incorrect Options: (A) Hemi-azygos Vein The hemi-azygos vein drains into the azygos vein. It is formed by the union of the lower left intercostal veins and typically drains into the azygos vein at the T8 level. Therefore, option (A) is incorrect because the hemi-azygos vein contributes to the azygos system. (B) Posterior Intercostal Vein The posterior intercostal veins drain into the azygos vein (on the right side) or into the hemi-azygos and accessory hemi-azygos veins (on the left side), which ultimately drain into the azygos vein. These veins are important for venous return from the intercostal spaces, making option (B) incorrect. (D) Right Superior Intercostal Vein The right superior intercostal vein drains into the azygos vein. It collects venous blood from the right upper intercostal spaces and conveys it into the azygos system. Therefore, option (D) is incorrect, as it is part of the azygos drainage pathway.

questions.text: Which of the following is not contained in the superior mediastinum?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Azygos Vein The azygos vein is not located in the superior mediastinum. Instead, it is situated in the posterior mediastinum, where it drains the posterior thoracic wall and empties into the superior vena cava. While it runs close to the spine and passes through the posterior aspect of the mediastinum, it does not lie in the superior mediastinum. Therefore, option (C) is the correct answer. Incorrect Options: (A) Thymus The thymus is located in the superior mediastinum, primarily in the anterior part of this region, behind the manubrium of the sternum. It plays a crucial role in immune system development, especially during childhood. Hence, option (A) is incorrect because the thymus is a structure contained in the superior mediastinum. (B) Great Vessels and Their Branches The great vessels (such as the aortic arch, brachiocephalic trunk, left common carotid artery, left subclavian artery, superior vena cava, and pulmonary arteries) and their branches are located in the superior mediastinum. These vessels are critical components of the circulatory system and lie in this region. Therefore, option (B) is incorrect as the great vessels are part of the superior mediastinum. (D) Trachea The trachea is located in the superior mediastinum, extending from the larynx down into the thoracic cavity where it bifurcates into the primary bronchi. It is an essential structure in the respiratory system, and its location in the superior mediastinum

questions.text: Azygous vein drain into :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Superior Vena Cava The azygos vein drains into the superior vena cava. It is a large vein located in the posterior thoracic wall that collects deoxygenated blood from the thoracic wall and abdominal wall (via its tributaries, including the hemi-azygos and accessory hemi-azygos veins). The azygos vein ascends on the right side of the vertebral column and eventually empties into the superior vena cava, just before it enters the heart. Therefore, option (C) is the correct answer. Incorrect Options: (A) Left Brachiocephalic Vein The left brachiocephalic vein is located on the left side of the chest and collects blood from the left arm and left side of the head, as well as from the left subclavian vein. However, the azygos vein does not drain into the left brachiocephalic vein. Instead, it drains into the superior vena cava on the right side, making option (A) incorrect. (B) Inferior Vena Cava The inferior vena cava drains deoxygenated blood from the lower half of the body (abdomen and legs) and ascends through the diaphragm into the right atrium. However, the azygos vein drains into the superior vena cava, not the inferior vena cava, making option (B) incorrect. (D) Right Brachiocephalic Vein The right brachiocephalic vein is formed by the union of the right subclavian vein and right internal jugular vein. It drains blood from the upper right side of the body. However, the azygos vein empties into the superior vena cava, not the right brachiocephalic vein.

questions.text: Superior epigastric artery is a branch of :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Internal Thoracic Artery The superior epigastric artery is a branch of the internal thoracic artery, which arises from the subclavian artery. The internal thoracic artery runs along the inner surface of the anterior chest wall, and one of its terminal branches, the superior epigastric artery, supplies blood to the upper abdominal wall. Therefore, option (C) is the correct answer. Incorrect Options: (A) Subclavian Artery The subclavian artery is the main artery that supplies blood to the upper limbs and part of the chest wall, but it does not directly give rise to the superior epigastric artery. The superior epigastric artery arises from the internal thoracic artery, which is a branch of the subclavian artery, not from the subclavian artery itself. Therefore, option (A) is incorrect. (B) Musculophrenic Artery The musculophrenic artery is another branch of the internal thoracic artery. It supplies the diaphragm and the lower intercostal spaces. However, it does not give rise to the superior epigastric artery, making option (B) incorrect. (D) Superior Intercostals Artery The superior intercostals artery typically arises from the costocervical trunk (a branch of the subclavian artery) and supplies the upper intercostal spaces. It does not give rise to the superior epigastric artery.

questions.text: All are insert in the first rib except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Scalenus Posterior The scalenus posterior does not insert into the first rib. Instead, it inserts onto the second rib. The scalenus posterior is one of the muscles of the scalene group in the neck, but unlike the scalenus anterior and scalenus medius, it does not attach to the first rib. Therefore, option (B) is the correct answer. Incorrect Options: (A) Scalenus Anterior The scalenus anterior muscle inserts onto the first rib. It originates from the transverse processes of the cervical vertebrae and inserts onto the scalene tubercle on the upper surface of the first rib. Therefore, option (A) is incorrect, as it does insert into the first rib. (C) Scalenus Medius The scalenus medius also inserts onto the first rib. It originates from the transverse processes of the cervical vertebrae and attaches to the superior surface of the first rib, just behind the insertion of the scalenus anterior. Therefore, option (C) is incorrect, as it too inserts into the first rib. (D) Supra Pleural Membrane The supra pleural membrane (also known as the Sibson's fascia) is a fibrous membrane that covers the apex of the lung and the top of the pleura. It is attached to the first rib and the transverse process of the cervical vertebra.

questions.text: Left superior intercostal vein drains into
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Left Brachiocephalic Vein The left superior intercostal vein drains into the left brachiocephalic vein. This vein collects blood from the left side of the upper chest and thorax, including the left upper intercostal veins, and ultimately drains into the left brachiocephalic vein. The left brachiocephalic vein then drains into the superior vena cava. Therefore, option (D) is the correct answer. Incorrect Options: (A) Azygous Vein The azygos vein drains blood from the right side of the thorax and does not receive drainage from the left superior intercostal vein. The azygos vein primarily receives blood from the right posterior intercostal veins, among other structures, but not from the left superior intercostal vein. Therefore, option (A) is incorrect. (B) Hemi Azygos Vein The hemi azygos vein drains the lower left posterior intercostal veins and then connects with the azygos vein, but it does not receive drainage from the left superior intercostal vein. The left superior intercostal vein drains directly into the left brachiocephalic vein, not the hemi azygos vein. Therefore, option (B) is incorrect. (C) Innominate Vein The innominate vein is another term for the brachiocephalic vein, but specifically refers to the right side in some contexts. Since the left superior intercostal vein drains into the left brachiocephalic vein, option (C) is less precise and would be incorrect, as the left side of the innominate (brachiocephalic) vein is the appropriate drainage route.

questions.text: Length of trachea -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 10-12 cm The length of the trachea typically measures between 10 and 12 cm in adults. The trachea extends from the cricoid cartilage at the level of the C6 vertebra to the carina, where it bifurcates into the left and right main bronchi. This length allows for adequate airway passage to the lungs. Therefore, option (A) is the correct answer. Incorrect Options: (B) 1 cm-10 cm The length of the trachea is not as short as 1 cm. It extends much longer than this range, typically between 10 to 12 cm in adults. Hence, option (B) is incorrect. (C) 15 cm While the trachea is approximately 10-12 cm in length, it does not usually extend as long as 15 cm. Therefore, option (C) is incorrect, as it overestimates the average length of the trachea. (D) 22.5 cm A length of 22.5 cm for the trachea is much too long. This length is significantly greater than the typical range of 10-12 cm.

questions.text: The stability of the vertebral column is due to -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) ALL The stability of the vertebral column is indeed a result of the combined contributions from all the structures mentioned: vertebrae and intervertebral discs, interspinous ligaments, and paraspinal muscles. These components work together to provide both static and dynamic stability to the spine. The vertebrae and intervertebral discs form the primary structural framework, while the ligaments (including the interspinous ligaments) provide passive support and prevent excessive movements. The paraspinal muscles contribute dynamic stability, allowing for controlled movement and posture. Therefore, option (D) is correct as all these structures contribute to the overall stability of the vertebral column. Incorrect Options: (A) Vertebra and Vertebral Discs While vertebrae and intervertebral discs are the primary structural components responsible for maintaining the stability of the spine, this option does not consider the additional role played by the ligaments and muscles. These components are also crucial for providing dynamic and passive stability. Thus, while option (A) is partially correct, it is incomplete and doesn't account for the full range of contributions to vertebral column stability. (B) Interspinous Ligaments The interspinous ligaments provide stability by limiting the motion between vertebrae, especially in the sagittal plane (flexion and extension). However, they alone do not provide full stability to the vertebral column, as the vertebrae and discs, along with paraspinal muscles, also contribute significantly to maintaining stability. Therefore, option (B) is not entirely correct by itself. (C) Paraspinal Muscles The paraspinal muscles play a crucial role in providing dynamic stability to the vertebral column, especially during movement. However, on their own, muscles cannot offer the same level of passive stability that is provided by the vertebrae, discs, and ligaments. Hence, while important, the muscles alone do not ensure the overall stability of the spine.

choices.text: Begins at the upper border of cricoid carlotilage

questions.text: The esophagus -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Is narrowest at its begining Here is a brief explanation for each option: A. Begins at the upper border of cricoid cartilage: This is incorrect. The esophagus actually begins at the level of the lower border of the cricoid cartilage. B. Runs a straight course throughout: This is incorrect. The esophagus has several natural curves as it follows the vertebral column and shifts to accommodate structures like the aortic arch. C. Is narrowest at its termination: This is incorrect. While the termination at the diaphragm is one of its three points of narrowing, the narrowest point overall is at its very beginning. D. Is narrowest at its beginning: This is the correct statement. The narrowest point of the esophagus is at the upper esophageal sphincter, formed by the cricopharyngeus muscle at its origin. This constriction is where swallowed objects are most likely to get lodged.

questions.text: The arch of aorta lies in the mediastinum -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Superior. The arch of the aorta lies in the superior mediastinum, which is the part of the mediastinum located above the heart and between the thoracic inlet and the level of the T4-T5 vertebrae. It arches over the heart and gives rise to the brachiocephalic trunk, left common carotid artery, and left subclavian artery before descending as the descending aorta. Incorrect responses: A. Posterior: This is incorrect because the arch of the aorta is not located in the posterior mediastinum. The posterior mediastinum contains structures like the descending thoracic aorta (below the arch), the azygos vein, and the esophagus, but not the arch of the aorta. B. Anterior: The arch of the aorta does not lie in the anterior mediastinum. The anterior mediastinum primarily contains fatty tissue, lymph nodes, and parts of the thymus. The aorta's arch is positioned more centrally and superiorly, not in the anterior part. C. Middle: This is incorrect because the middle mediastinum contains the heart, pericardium, and parts of large vessels like the pulmonary arteries and veins, but not the aortic arch. The aortic arch is located in the superior mediastinum, not in the middle.

questions.text: Which of the following do NOT elevate the ribs -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Serratus posterior inferior. The serratus posterior inferior muscle does not elevate the ribs; instead, it depresses the lower ribs (ribs 9-12). This muscle helps in forced expiration by pulling the lower ribs downward, assisting with exhalation. Incorrect responses: A. Serratus posterior superior: This muscle elevates the upper ribs (ribs 2-5). It helps with inhalation by pulling the ribs upward and outward, increasing the thoracic volume. Therefore, this muscle does elevate the ribs. C. External intercostals: The external intercostals are responsible for elevating the ribs during inspiration. They are situated between the ribs and work to expand the thoracic cavity by lifting the ribs upward and outward, aiding in inhalation. D. Levatores costarum: The levatores costarum are small muscles that elevate the ribs. They originate from the transverse processes of the vertebrae and insert onto the ribs, pulling them upward during inspiration.

questions.text: Superior intercostal artery is a branch of-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Costocervical trunk. The superior intercostal artery arises from the costocervical trunk, which itself is a branch of the subclavian artery. The superior intercostal artery supplies the first two posterior intercostal spaces (the 1st and 2nd intercostal arteries) and contributes to the blood supply of the upper part of the chest wall. Incorrect responses: B. Dorsal scapular artery: The dorsal scapular artery is typically a branch of the subclavian artery or sometimes the transverse cervical artery. It supplies the muscles around the scapula, particularly the rhomboid muscles, but it does not supply the intercostal spaces, making it an incorrect answer. C. Thyrocervical trunk: The thyrocervical trunk is a branch of the subclavian artery that gives rise to vessels supplying the thyroid gland, parathyroid glands, and neck muscles. It does not give rise to the superior intercostal artery, so it is not the correct answer. D. Internal thoracic artery: The internal thoracic artery arises from the subclavian artery and gives rise to branches that supply the anterior chest wall and the breasts, but it does not supply the superior intercostal spaces,

questions.text: All of the following structures pass through the superior aperture of thorax except -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Right recurrent laryngeal nerve. The right recurrent laryngeal nerve does not pass through the superior aperture of the thorax (also known as the thoracic inlet). Instead, the right recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the right subclavian artery, which is located beneath the clavicle, and then ascends to the larynx. Therefore, it does not pass directly through the thoracic inlet, making it the correct choice. Incorrect responses: B. Left common carotid artery: The left common carotid artery passes through the superior aperture of the thorax. It arises from the aortic arch and ascends into the neck to supply the head and neck with oxygenated blood. The left common carotid artery is one of the major structures that pass through the thoracic inlet. C. Left sympathetic trunk: The left sympathetic trunk passes through the superior aperture of the thorax. It is part of the autonomic nervous system and runs along the vertebral column, sending out branches to various organs. The sympathetic trunk runs through the thoracic inlet as it continues into the thoracic cavity. D. Thoracic duct: The thoracic duct is the largest lymphatic vessel in the body and also passes through the superior aperture of the thorax. It collects lymph from most of the body and drains into the venous system at the junction of the left internal jugular and subclavian veins.

choices.text: In the center of the intercostal space
In anterior part of intercostal space

questions.text: While doing thoracocentesis, it is advisable to introduce needle along â€“
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Upper border of the rib. During thoracocentesis, the needle should be introduced along the upper border of the rib to avoid injury to the neurovascular bundle that runs along the lower border of each rib. The neurovascular bundle contains the intercostal nerves, arteries, and veins, which are vulnerable to puncture if the needle is inserted along the lower border. By introducing the needle just above the rib, you minimize the risk of damaging these important structures. Incorrect responses: B. Lower border of the rib: The lower border of the rib is the incorrect location for needle insertion during thoracocentesis because this is where the neurovascular bundle (intercostal nerve, artery, and vein) runs. Inserting the needle here could potentially cause injury to these vessels and nerves, leading to complications. C. In the center of the intercostal space: Inserting the needle in the center of the intercostal space is not advisable, as the neurovascular bundle lies near the lower border of the ribs. In the center of the intercostal space, there is still a risk of puncturing the intercostal vessels and nerves, so it is safer to avoid this area. D. In the anterior part of the intercostal space: Inserting the needle in the anterior part of the intercostal space is not recommended because the anterior intercostal arteries and veins, as well as the nerves, are more likely to be closer to the needle's path in this area. It's typically better to perform the procedure closer to the mid-axillary line or along the upper border of the rib to avoid complications.

questions.text: The internal thoracic veins are tributaries of the-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Brachiocephalic. Explanation of the correct response: D. Brachiocephalic: The internal thoracic veins (also known as internal mammary veins) drain the anterior chest wall and the breasts. These veins ultimately drain into the brachiocephalic veins. The right and left brachiocephalic veins merge to form the superior vena cava, which returns deoxygenated blood to the heart. Therefore, the internal thoracic veins are tributaries of the brachiocephalic vein, making this statement correct. Explanation of the incorrect responses: A. Azygos: The azygos vein mainly drains the posterior thoracic wall and parts of the abdomen. It is not the direct recipient of the internal thoracic veins, though both the azygos and internal thoracic veins contribute to venous drainage of the thorax. Therefore, this statement is incorrect. B. Subclavian: The subclavian vein drains the upper limb and parts of the neck, but it does not directly receive drainage from the internal thoracic veins. The internal thoracic veins drain into the brachiocephalic veins, not the subclavian veins. Therefore, this statement is incorrect. C. Internal jugular: The internal jugular veins primarily drain blood from the brain, neck, and face, and they do not directly receive blood from the internal thoracic veins. The internal thoracic veins drain into the brachiocephalic vein, not the internal jugular. Therefore,

questions.text: The normal narrowing in the middle of the oesophagus is caused by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) D. Left main bronchus: The normal narrowing of the esophagus at the level where the left main bronchus crosses it occurs due to anatomical positioning. The left main bronchus passes posteriorly and to the left of the esophagus, creating a natural constriction in this region. This is one of the normal anatomical constrictions of the esophagus, often referred to as the "bronchial narrowing" of the esophagus. Therefore, this statement is correct. Explanation of the incorrect responses: A. Azygos vein: The azygos vein lies in the posterior mediastinum and drains blood from the thoracic wall. It arches over the right main bronchus and does not cause a narrowing in the middle of the esophagus. Therefore, this statement is incorrect. B. Hemiazygos vein: The hemiazygos vein also drains blood from the left side of the posterior thoracic wall and joins the azygos vein. It crosses the midline of the thorax, but it does not cause a narrowing of the esophagus. Therefore, this statement is incorrect. C. Right main bronchus: The right main bronchus does cross over the esophagus, but it does not cause a narrowing at the middle part of the esophagus. The right bronchus is anatomically positioned posterior to the esophagus, but it is the left main bronchus that is more closely associated with the esophageal narrowing in the middle. Therefore, this statement is incorrect.

questions.text: The last tributary of the azygos vein is -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) C. Right bronchial vein: The right bronchial vein is the last tributary of the azygos vein. It drains the bronchial tree and adjacent structures in the right lung and contributes directly to the azygos vein. This makes the right bronchial vein the final tributary before the azygos vein drains into the superior vena cava. Therefore, this statement is correct. Explanation of the incorrect responses: A. Right superior intercostal vein: The right superior intercostal vein drains the upper intercostal spaces (typically the 1st to 3rd intercostal spaces) and empties into the azygos vein. However, it is not the last tributary. It drains into the azygos vein earlier, not as the final tributary. Therefore, this statement is incorrect. B. Hemi-azygos vein: The hemiazygos vein drains the left side of the lower thorax and drains into the azygos vein at a lower level (typically around T9). It does not serve as the last tributary of the azygos vein. Therefore, this statement is incorrect. D. Accessory azygos vein: The accessory azygos vein drains the 4th to 8th intercostal spaces on the left side and empties into the azygos vein, but it is not the final tributary. Like the hemi-azygos vein, it contributes to the azygos vein before the right bronchial vein does. Therefore, this statement is incorrect.

choices.text: Superior articular facet is directed backwards & upwards

questions.text: All of the following characteristics differentiate a typical cervical vertebra from a thoracic vertebra except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Has a large vertebral body) D. Has a large vertebral body: A typical cervical vertebra does not have a large vertebral body, which distinguishes it from a thoracic vertebra. Cervical vertebrae have small, oval-shaped bodies because they primarily support the weight of the head, while thoracic vertebrae have larger, heart-shaped bodies to support more substantial loads from the thorax and upper limbs. Thus, the presence of a large vertebral body is not a characteristic that differentiates cervical vertebrae from thoracic vertebrae, making this the correct answer. Explanation for the Incorrect Options: A. Has a triangular vertebral canal: Cervical vertebrae have a triangular-shaped vertebral canal, which is broader to accommodate the cervical enlargement of the spinal cord. In contrast, thoracic vertebrae have a smaller, circular vertebral canal. This feature clearly differentiates cervical vertebrae from thoracic vertebrae. B. Has foramen transversarium: A hallmark feature of cervical vertebrae is the presence of foramen transversarium in their transverse processes. This foramen transmits the vertebral artery and vein, a feature absent in thoracic vertebrae, which instead have costal facets for rib articulation. C. Superior articular facet is directed backwards & upwards: In cervical vertebrae, the superior articular facets are oriented backwards and upwards, enabling greater mobility in the neck region. In thoracic vertebrae, the superior articular facets are more vertically oriented to support the thoracic cage and limit excessive motion.

questions.text: Which of the following duct commences in the abdomen as an elongated lymph sac of the cisterna chyli is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Thoracic duct A. Thoracic duct: The thoracic duct is the largest lymphatic vessel in the body. It begins in the abdomen as the cisterna chyli, an elongated lymph sac located at the level of the second lumbar vertebra (L2). The cisterna chyli collects lymph from the lower limbs, pelvis, and abdomen. From there, the thoracic duct ascends through the diaphragm via the aortic hiatus and continues into the thorax, ultimately draining into the junction of the left subclavian and internal jugular veins. This description aligns with the correct anatomical course and function of the thoracic duct, making it the correct answer. Explanation for the Incorrect Options: B. Gartner's duct: Gartner's duct is a vestigial remnant of the mesonephric duct in females and does not have a role in the lymphatic system. It is unrelated to the cisterna chyli or the thoracic duct, making this option incorrect. C. Bile duct: The bile duct is part of the biliary system and carries bile from the liver and gallbladder to the duodenum for digestion. It is unrelated to the lymphatic system or the cisterna chyli, and thus, this option is incorrect. D. Hepatic duct: The hepatic duct is a part of the biliary tree, transporting bile from the liver to the common bile duct. It has no connection to the lymphatic system or the thoracic duct,

questions.text: The thoracic duct receives tributaries from all of the following except -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Right bronchomediastinal lymphatic trunk. The thoracic duct is the main lymphatic vessel in the body, which collects lymph from most of the body and drains into the left venous angle. However, the right bronchomediastinal lymphatic trunk does not drain into the thoracic duct. Instead, it empties directly into the right subclavian vein or right internal jugular vein, bypassing the thoracic duct. Therefore, it is not a tributary of the thoracic duct. Incorrect Answers: A. Bilateral ascending lumbar trunk: The ascending lumbar trunks are part of the lymphatic drainage system that ultimately drains into the thoracic duct. These trunks receive lymph from the lower limbs and pelvis, and they contribute to the formation of the thoracic duct. B. Bilateral descending thoracic trunk: The descending thoracic trunks are tributaries that drain lymph from the lower part of the thorax and abdominal region. These trunks contribute to the flow of lymph into the thoracic duct. C. Left upper intercostal duct: The left upper intercostal duct drains lymph from the left side of the upper thoracic wall and intercostal spaces. It empties into the thoracic duct, making it a tributary of the thoracic duct.

choices.text: Nerve supply from long thoracic nerve
Inserted into bicipital groove of humerus
Blood supply from lateral thoracic artery

questions.text: True about Latissimus dorsi â€“
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Inserted into bicipital groove of humerus. The latissimus dorsi is a large muscle of the back that plays a key role in shoulder movement. It inserts into the bicipital groove (also known as the intertubercular sulcus) of the humerus. This insertion allows the muscle to facilitate actions like shoulder adduction, extension, and internal rotation. Incorrect Answers: A. Nerve supply from long thoracic nerve: The long thoracic nerve supplies the serratus anterior muscle, not the latissimus dorsi. The latissimus dorsi is innervated by the thoracodorsal nerve, which is a branch of the brachial plexus. C. Origin from upper four ribs: The latissimus dorsi does not originate from the upper four ribs. Its origin is from the lower six thoracic vertebrae (T7-T12), the lumbar vertebrae, the iliac crest, and the lower three or four ribs. Therefore, it does not have its origin from the upper four ribs. D. Blood supply from lateral thoracic artery: The lateral thoracic artery primarily supplies the serratus anterior and parts of the breast tissue. The latissimus dorsi receives its blood supply from the thoracodorsal artery, a branch of the subscapular artery.

questions.text: In a Subclavian artery block at the outer border of 1st rib, all of the following arteries help in maintaining the circulation to upper limb except -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Superior thoracic. In the case of a subclavian artery block at the outer border of the 1st rib, collateral circulation is essential to maintain blood flow to the upper limb. The superior thoracic artery is primarily involved in supplying blood to the chest wall and the upper part of the thorax and does not significantly contribute to the collateral circulation of the upper limb in this scenario. It is not part of the network that compensates for a blocked subclavian artery, unlike the other arteries mentioned. Now, let's look at the incorrect responses: A. Subscapular artery: The subscapular artery plays a significant role in collateral circulation when there is a blockage of the subclavian artery. It is a branch of the axillary artery and can provide an alternate route for blood to flow to the upper limb via its branches like the scapular arteries. These collateral pathways are crucial in maintaining upper limb circulation. C. Thyrocervical trunk: The thyrocervical trunk is a branch of the subclavian artery that supplies blood to the neck, thyroid gland, and upper part of the chest. It gives off several important branches, including the inferior thyroid artery, the transverse cervical artery, and the suprascapular artery, all of which contribute to maintaining circulation to the upper limb in case of a blockage of the subclavian artery. D. Suprascapular artery: The suprascapular artery, a branch of the thyrocervical trunk, also plays a role in collateral circulation by supplying the scapular region and the shoulder. It is involved in maintaining the blood flow to the upper limb during a subclavian artery block, supporting the alternate routes of blood supply to the arm and shoulder region.

questions.text: Hassall's corpuscles are seen in â€“
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Thymus Hassall's corpuscles are unique structures found in the medulla of the thymus. They are formed by clusters of keratinized epithelial cells arranged in concentric layers. These corpuscles are involved in the development and regulation of T lymphocytes (T cells) and may play a role in the removal of apoptotic thymocytes or in modulating immune responses through cytokine production. Their presence is a histological hallmark of the thymus, and they are not found in any other organ, making this the correct answer. Incorrect Responses: (B) Thyroid This option is incorrect because the thyroid gland is involved in the production of thyroid hormones (T3 and T4) and calcitonin, and it does not contain Hassall's corpuscles. The thyroid gland is composed of follicular and parafollicular cells but lacks the epithelial clusters characteristic of Hassall's corpuscles. (C) Parathyroid This option is incorrect as the parathyroid glands are responsible for calcium homeostasis through the production of parathyroid hormone (PTH). They consist of chief cells and oxyphil cells but do not contain structures resembling Hassall's corpuscles. (D) Spleen This option is incorrect because the spleen functions as a blood filter and immune organ, primarily involved in the removal of old red blood cells and the production of immune responses. It contains white pulp (lymphoid tissue) and red pulp (vascular tissue) but lacks Hassall's corpuscles.

questions.text: At what level does the trachea bifurcates?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Lower border of T6 The trachea bifurcates into the right and left main bronchi at the carina, which is located at the lower border of T6 vertebra. This anatomical landmark is slightly variable and depends on factors such as respiration and body position. During deep inspiration, the carina may be slightly lower due to the downward movement of the thoracic cavity. The carina is a critical structure for airway anatomy and is a key point during bronchoscopy and other respiratory procedures. Incorrect Responses: (A) Upper border of T4 This option is incorrect because the bifurcation of the trachea typically occurs below this level. The upper border of T4 is closer to the level of the aortic arch, which lies superior to the carina. (B) Lower border of T4 This option is incorrect as the lower border of T4 is the level of the sternal angle (Angle of Louis). Although this level corresponds to the approximate location of the carina in a supine individual, the correct level is typically described as lower border of T6 when accounting for variability and functional anatomy in upright positions. (C) 27.5 cm from the incisors This option is incorrect because the distance from the incisors to the tracheal bifurcation varies based on factors like age, body size, and procedural measurement methods. While 27.5 cm may approximate the carina's distance from the incisors during intubation or bronchoscopy, it is not a universally accurate or consistent anatomical landmark.

questions.text: Distance of the Lower Esophageal Sphincter from the upper incisors is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 37.5cm The lower esophageal sphincter (LES), also known as the gastroesophageal junction, is located approximately 37.5 cm from the upper incisors in adults. This measurement is taken during esophagoscopy or endoscopy, using the upper incisors as a reference point. The LES serves as a functional barrier that prevents the reflux of gastric contents into the esophagus. Its position at 37.5 cm is consistent across most individuals and is an important anatomical landmark in diagnosing and treating esophageal and gastric disorders. Incorrect Responses: (A) 15 cm This option is incorrect because 15 cm corresponds to the distance from the upper incisors to the beginning of the cervical esophagus, where the esophagus starts at the level of the cricopharyngeus muscle. It is far above the location of the LES. (B) 22.5 cm This option is incorrect because 22.5 cm corresponds to the level of the mid-thoracic esophagus or the level of the aortic arch. The LES is significantly lower in the thoracic cavity. (C) 27.5 cm This option is incorrect as 27.5 cm corresponds to the distal thoracic esophagus near the esophageal hiatus but not at the LES. The LES is further down, at 37.5 cm.

questions.text: Hemiazygous vein crosses left to right at the level of-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) T8 The hemiazygous vein crosses from left to right at the level of T8. The hemiazygous vein is a tributary of the azygos vein, which drains the left posterior thoracic wall and parts of the abdomen. The hemiazygous vein ascends on the left side of the vertebral column, and at the level of T8, it crosses over to the right side to join the azygos vein. This connection is important for venous return from the lower parts of the body and the thoracic cavity. Incorrect Responses: (B) T10 This option is incorrect because the hemiazygous vein crosses over to the right side at the level of T8, not T10. At T10, the azygos system is present, but the hemiazygous vein has already crossed to the right side earlier, at T8. (C) T12 This option is incorrect because T12 corresponds to the level of the diaphragm, and at this level, the hemiazygous vein is not crossing. It is still lower and on the left side before it ascends towards T8. (D) T6 This option is incorrect because the hemiazygous vein does not cross over to the right at T6. The crossing occurs later at T8, and at T6, the hemiazygous vein is still on the left side of the vertebral column.

questions.text: Thoracic duct ends at-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) C7 The thoracic duct drains into the left subclavian vein at the level of C7 or slightly above it, where the internal jugular vein and the subclavian vein meet to form the left venous angle. The thoracic duct is the largest lymphatic vessel in the body, carrying lymph from the lower body, the left side of the upper body, and the head and neck to the bloodstream. The convergence point where the thoracic duct empties into the venous system is located at the level of the C7 vertebra, making this the correct answer. Incorrect Responses: (A) T1 This option is incorrect because the thoracic duct does not end at the level of T1. The thoracic duct continues to ascend towards the left venous angle at the level of C7, not T1. T1 is higher than the actual termination point of the thoracic duct. (C) T5 This option is incorrect because the thoracic duct is located in the posterior mediastinum, but it does not end at the level of T5. By T5, the thoracic duct is still in the process of ascending, and it eventually drains into the venous system at the level of C7. (D) T8 This option is incorrect because the thoracic duct does not empty at the level of T8. It continues to ascend and drains into the left venous angle at C7. T8 is lower than the actual termination point of the thoracic duct.

questions.text: Blood supply of thoracic part of esophagus -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Aorta The thoracic part of the esophagus receives its primary blood supply from branches of the aorta. Specifically, the esophageal arteries arise from the descending aorta and supply the thoracic portion of the esophagus. These arteries are responsible for providing oxygenated blood to the esophageal tissues, supporting its functions of food propulsion and digestion. Incorrect Responses: (B) Inferior thyroid artery This option is incorrect because the inferior thyroid artery supplies blood to the thyroid gland and the surrounding neck structures, not the esophagus. It primarily serves the lower part of the thyroid and does not play a significant role in the blood supply to the thoracic esophagus. (C) Gastric artery This option is incorrect because the gastric artery (which includes branches such as the left gastric artery) supplies blood to the stomach and proximal part of the duodenum, not the thoracic esophagus. The gastric artery is part of the abdominal circulation, and while it supplies the esophagus in the abdominal region, it does not contribute to the blood supply of the thoracic esophagus. (D) Superior thyroid artery This option is incorrect because the superior thyroid artery supplies the upper part of the thyroid gland and the surrounding neck muscles. It does not supply the thoracic portion of the esophagus. The blood supply to the esophagus in the thoracic cavity is primarily from branches of the aorta.

questions.text: The blood supply of breast is by all the following arteries except â€“
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Thoracodorsal artery The thoracodorsal artery is not a primary blood supply to the breast. It mainly supplies the latissimus dorsi muscle and surrounding tissues, not the breast. Though it has some minor contributions to the breast tissue, it is not one of the primary arteries that supply the breast. Incorrect Responses: (B) Thoracoacromial artery This option is incorrect because the thoracoacromial artery is indeed a major contributor to the blood supply of the breast. It arises from the subclavian artery and gives off a pectoral branch that supplies the breast, particularly the superior part of the breast. (C) Lateral thoracic artery This option is incorrect because the lateral thoracic artery is one of the primary arteries supplying the breast. It arises from the axillary artery and provides blood to the lateral part of the breast, including the mammary gland and the skin overlying it. (D) Internal thoracic artery This option is incorrect because the internal thoracic artery (also known as the internal mammary artery) is a major artery supplying the breast. It provides blood to the medial aspect of the breast and is an important vessel for the arterial supply, especially for the inner portions of the breast.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is enclosed within the clavipectoral fascia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Subclavius The subclavius muscle is the muscle that is enclosed within the clavipectoral fascia. The clavipectoral fascia is a connective tissue structure that extends between the clavicle and the pectoralis minor muscle, and it envelops the subclavius muscle as well. This fascia provides support and helps anchor the muscle to the surrounding structures, including the clavicle. It plays an important role in the stabilizing function of the shoulder. Incorrect Responses: (A) Pectoralis major This option is incorrect because the pectoralis major muscle is not enclosed by the clavipectoral fascia. The pectoralis major is located more superficially, and while the clavipectoral fascia does lie beneath it, the muscle itself is not enclosed by this fascia. It is more closely associated with the chest wall. (B) Serratus anterior This option is incorrect because the serratus anterior muscle is not enclosed by the clavipectoral fascia. The serratus anterior is located on the lateral chest wall and is responsible for protracting and stabilizing the scapula. It lies deep to the pectoralis minor and is not surrounded by the clavipectoral fascia. (C) Coracobrachialis This option is incorrect because the coracobrachialis muscle is not enclosed within the clavipectoral fascia. It is a muscle of the upper arm, originating from the coracoid process of the scapula and inserting on the humerus. It is not associated with the clavipectoral fascia, which mainly covers muscles in the thoracic region, like the subclavius.

questions.text: Trachea is lined by ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Pseudostratified columnar The trachea is lined by pseudostratified columnar epithelium, which is a type of epithelium that appears to be stratified (layered), but all the cells actually touch the basement membrane, making it a type of simple epithelium. This epithelium is specialized for the respiratory tract and is equipped with cilia and goblet cells. The cilia help move mucus and trapped particles up the respiratory tract, while the goblet cells secrete mucus to trap foreign particles, providing a protective mechanism for the airway. Incorrect Responses: (A) Simple columnar This option is incorrect because simple columnar epithelium is not found in the trachea. Simple columnar epithelium is typically found in areas such as the digestive tract, where it aids in absorption and secretion. The trachea's lining is more specialized for protection and movement of mucus, which is why it has pseudostratified columnar epithelium. (C) Simple cuboidal This option is incorrect because simple cuboidal epithelium is typically found in glandular tissues and in areas of secretion and absorption, such as in ducts and tubules (e.g., kidney tubules). The trachea does not have simple cuboidal epithelium because it needs a more specialized structure (pseudostratified columnar) to handle mucus movement and protection. (D) Stratified squamous, non-keratinized This option is incorrect because stratified squamous epithelium is usually found in areas subjected to significant abrasion, such as the skin or the oral cavity. The trachea is not subjected to this type of abrasion and requires a different type of epithelium to facilitate the movement of mucus and protect the airway, which is provided by pseudostratified columnar epithelium.

choices.text: Is the demarcation plane between superior and inferior mediastinum
Passes anteriorly from sternal angle to posteriorly T4 disc
Is an important anatomical and radiological marking
Passes through the cardiac chambers in normal subjects

questions.text: Select the statement NOT true with respected to transverse thoracic plane-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Passes through the cardiac chambers in normal subjects This statement is NOT true because the transverse thoracic plane does not pass through the cardiac chambers in normal subjects. The transverse thoracic plane is a horizontal plane that runs at the level of the sternal angle (T2-T3) anteriorly and the T4-T5 disc posteriorly. It demarcates the superior and inferior mediastinum, and is an important landmark for various structures in the thorax, but it does not pass through the chambers of the heart. The heart's chambers are situated in a more central position in the thorax and are not directly intersected by this plane. Incorrect Responses: (A) Is the demarcation plane between superior and inferior mediastinum This statement is true. The transverse thoracic plane is indeed the anatomical plane that separates the superior mediastinum (which contains structures like the thymus, trachea, and great vessels) from the inferior mediastinum (which contains the heart, diaphragm, and lower parts of the great vessels). (B) Passes anteriorly from sternal angle to posteriorly T4 disc This statement is true. The transverse thoracic plane runs from the sternal angle at the level of T2-T3 anteriorly, to the T4-T5 disc posteriorly, making it a crucial anatomical reference point in both clinical and radiological settings. (C) Is an important anatomical and radiological marking This statement is true. The transverse thoracic plane is widely used in both anatomy and radiology as a key marker for dividing the mediastinum into superior and inferior parts, as well as for identifying important structures at this level, such as the bifurcation of the trachea and the arch of the aorta.

choices.text: 1st pair of ribs and their costal cartilage

questions.text: Superior thoracic aperture is bounded by following EXCEPT
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Xiphoid process The xiphoid process is NOT a boundary of the superior thoracic aperture. The xiphoid process is the lower, cartilaginous part of the sternum and is located at the inferior end of the sternum. It is part of the inferior boundary of the thoracic cavity but is not involved in the formation of the superior thoracic aperture. The superior thoracic aperture is at the top of the thoracic cavity and does not include the xiphoid process in its boundary. Incorrect Responses: (A) T1 vertebra This statement is true. The T1 vertebra forms the posterior boundary of the superior thoracic aperture. It is located at the level of the first thoracic vertebra, which is one of the boundaries of the opening. (B) 1st pair of ribs and their costal cartilage This statement is true. The first pair of ribs, along with their associated costal cartilage, form the lateral boundary of the superior thoracic aperture. The first rib arches over and contributes to the definition of the opening at the top of the thorax. (C) Superior border of the manubrium This statement is true. The superior border of the manubrium of the sternum forms the anterior boundary of the superior thoracic aperture. The manubrium is the upper part of the sternum, and its superior border helps define the opening to the thoracic cavity.

questions.text: Oesophagus is present in which mediastinum
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Posterior Mediastinum The esophagus is located in the posterior mediastinum, which is the region of the mediastinum that lies behind the pericardium and between the thoracic vertebrae. The esophagus passes through the posterior mediastinum, running behind the trachea and aorta. It extends from the level of the 6th cervical vertebra to the 10th thoracic vertebra, where it enters the diaphragm. This positioning places the esophagus firmly within the posterior mediastinal space. Incorrect Responses: (A) Anterior Mediastinum This statement is incorrect because the anterior mediastinum is the space located between the sternum and the anterior surface of the pericardium. It contains structures such as the thymus, fat, and lymph nodes, but not the esophagus. The esophagus is much deeper and located in the posterior part of the thoracic cavity. (C) Middle Mediastinum This statement is incorrect because the middle mediastinum is the area containing the heart and its surrounding structures, including the pericardium and the great vessels such as the aorta, pulmonary arteries, and veins. The esophagus is not located here; it is situated behind the heart, in the posterior mediastinum. (D) None This option is incorrect because the esophagus is clearly located in the posterior mediastinum, making the "None" option incorrect.

questions.text: False rib is -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 10th A false rib refers to a rib that does not directly connect to the sternum through its own costal cartilage. Instead, the 10th rib (and the 11th and 12th ribs) are classified as false ribs because they attach to the costal cartilage of the rib above (the 9th rib's cartilage) rather than directly connecting to the sternum. These ribs are considered "false" because they do not have a direct attachment to the sternum. The 10th rib is also floating in some cases, particularly in terms of the cartilage connection, although the rib itself is still part of the ribcage. Incorrect Responses: (A) 1st This is incorrect because the 1st rib is a true rib, meaning it attaches directly to the sternum via its own costal cartilage. True ribs are those that have a direct connection to the sternum, and the 1st rib is one of them. (B) 2nd This is incorrect because the 2nd rib is also a true rib, like the 1st rib, because it connects directly to the sternum. The 2nd rib attaches to the sternum via its own costal cartilage, and it is not considered a false rib. (C) 6th This is incorrect because the 6th rib is also a true rib. Like the 1st and 2nd ribs, it attaches directly to the sternum through its own costal cartilage and is not classified as a false rib.

questions.text: Which of following is attached to first rib-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Scalenus medius The scalenus medius muscle is attached to the first rib. It is one of the three scalene muscles located in the neck, and its origin is from the transverse processes of the cervical vertebrae (C1 to C7). The muscle inserts into the upper surface of the first rib, making it responsible for the elevation of the first rib during inspiration and contributing to lateral flexion of the neck. This muscle is also important for its role in nerve and vessel passage, with the brachial plexus and subclavian artery passing between the scalenus anterior and scalenus medius. Incorrect Responses: (A) Scalenus posterior This is incorrect because the scalenus posterior does not attach to the first rib. It actually attaches to the second rib and plays a role in elevating the second rib. The scalenus posterior is located behind the scalenus medius, but it does not have any attachment to the first rib. (B) Serratus posterior superior This is incorrect because the serratus posterior superior does not attach to the first rib. Instead, it attaches to the upper ribs (2nd to 5th) and plays a role in elevating these ribs during inspiration. It is not connected to the first rib. (D) None of the above This is incorrect because option (C) is the correct answer. The scalenus medius is the muscle attached to the first rib, so "None of the above" is not the right choice.

questions.text: 8, 9 & 10th ribs are attached to 7th rib by which joint
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Synovial The 8th, 9th, and 10th ribs are attached to the 7th rib by fibrous joints. This type of joint is known as a costal cartilage joint, where the costal cartilages of the 8th, 9th, and 10th ribs are connected indirectly through a shared fibrous connection to the costal cartilage of the 7th rib. These fibrous joints do not allow for significant movement, and they provide a stable but flexible connection, important for the expansion of the rib cage during breathing. Incorrect Responses: (A) Fibrous This is incorrect, as this option is just a repeated version of (B) and does not provide the correct answer as it would be redundant. The correct answer, as explained, is the fibrous joint between the ribs, not a standalone fibrous option. (C) 1st cartilaginous This is incorrect because the 1st costal cartilage joint refers to the connection between the first rib and the manubrium of the sternum, which is a synchondrosis joint (a type of cartilaginous joint). The 8th, 9th, and 10th ribs do not connect to the 7th rib through this type of cartilage. (D) 2nd cartilaginous This is incorrect because this refers to secondary cartilaginous joints, which are seen between other joints, like the connection between the vertebrae, not between the ribs. The 8th, 9th, and 10th ribs connect to the 7th rib through a fibrous joint, not a cartilaginous joint.

questions.text: Thoracic duct does not drains
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Right upper part of body The thoracic duct is responsible for draining the left side of the body (including the left upper limb, left side of the head, neck, and chest) and the lower half of the body (both left and right sides below the diaphragm). However, it does not drain the right upper part of the body. The right upper part of the body is drained by the right lymphatic duct, which is separate from the thoracic duct. The thoracic duct empties into the left subclavian vein near the junction of the internal jugular vein. Incorrect Responses: (B) Left upper part of body This is incorrect because the left upper part of the body is drained by the thoracic duct, along with the rest of the left side and the lower half of the body. The thoracic duct collects lymph from the left side of the head, neck, chest, left arm, and lower body. (C) Right lower part of body This is incorrect because the right lower part of the body is drained by the thoracic duct as well. The thoracic duct drains lymph from both the right and left lower limbs, so it includes the lower half of the body on both sides. (D) Left lower part of body This is incorrect because the left lower part of the body is drained by the thoracic duct. The thoracic duct is responsible for the lymphatic drainage of the entire lower body, including the left side and right side below the diaphragm.

questions.text: Right superior intercostal vein drains into
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Azygos vein The right superior intercostal vein typically drains into the azygos vein, which is a major vein that drains the posterior thoracic wall and upper lumbar region. The azygos vein is responsible for returning deoxygenated blood from the thoracic wall to the superior vena cava. It receives blood from the right side of the posterior intercostal veins and the right superior intercostal vein. Incorrect Responses: (A) Brachiocephalic vein This is incorrect because the right superior intercostal vein does not directly drain into the brachiocephalic vein. The brachiocephalic veins are formed by the union of the internal jugular vein and subclavian vein, and they drain into the superior vena cava. The right superior intercostal vein drains into the azygos vein, not the brachiocephalic vein. (C) IVC (Inferior Vena Cava) This is incorrect because the inferior vena cava drains blood from the lower body and abdomen, but not directly from the intercostal veins. The right superior intercostal vein drains into the azygos vein, which then empties into the superior vena cava, and not the inferior vena cava. (D) None of the above This is incorrect because option (B) Azygos vein is the correct answer. The right superior intercostal vein indeed drains into the azygos vein, making this option wrong.

questions.text: The costal cartilages of these ribs do not reach the sternum
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 11th & 12th The 11th and 12th ribs are classified as floating ribs, and their costal cartilages do not attach to the sternum or any other ribs. These ribs are shorter and have no anterior attachment to the sternum, making them distinct from the other ribs. This is why the correct answer is A. Incorrect Responses: (B) 1st & 2nd The 1st and 2nd ribs are true ribs. The costal cartilage of the 1st rib attaches directly to the manubrium of the sternum, while the costal cartilage of the 2nd rib connects to the sternum at the sternal angle. Therefore, both ribs have a direct attachment to the sternum, making B incorrect. (C) 6th & 7th The 6th and 7th ribs are true ribs, meaning their costal cartilages connect to the sternum directly or through the costal cartilage of the rib above them. Thus, they do indeed reach the sternum, and C is incorrect. (D) 8th, 9th & 10th The 8th, 9th, and 10th ribs are false ribs, meaning their costal cartilages do not directly connect to the sternum but instead connect to the costal cartilage of the rib above. While these ribs do not connect directly to the sternum, their cartilages still articulate with those of the ribs above.

questions.text: All of the following are contents of middle mediastinum except -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Arch of aorta The arch of aorta is not a content of the middle mediastinum. It is located in the superior mediastinum. The arch of aorta arches from the left side of the heart and gives off branches such as the brachiocephalic trunk, left common carotid artery, and left subclavian artery, which are located in the superior mediastinum, above the level of the middle mediastinum. Hence, C is correct. Incorrect Responses: (A) Phrenic nerve The phrenic nerve is a content of the middle mediastinum. It runs along the pericardium and supplies the diaphragm with motor and sensory innervation. The nerve passes through the diaphragm to reach the abdominal cavity. Therefore, A is incorrect. (B) Ascending aorta The ascending aorta is a content of the middle mediastinum. It arises from the left ventricle of the heart and carries oxygenated blood to the body. The ascending aorta is positioned in the middle mediastinum, and its root is surrounded by the pericardium. Therefore, B is incorrect. (D) Pulmonary artery The pulmonary artery is also located in the middle mediastinum. It arises from the right ventricle and transports deoxygenated blood to the lungs for oxygenation. The pulmonary artery is located just behind the ascending aorta and is part of the contents of the middle mediastinum.

questions.text: Thoracic duct crosses from right side to left side at which vertebral level
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) T5 The thoracic duct crosses from the right side to the left side at the T5 vertebral level. It ascends along the right side of the vertebral column, passes behind the aortic arch, and then crosses over to the left side at the level of T5. This is an important anatomical landmark as it marks the point where the thoracic duct shifts direction, moving from the right side to the left before it drains into the left subclavian vein. Hence, B is correct. Incorrect Responses: (A) T10 At the T10 vertebral level, the thoracic duct is still in the abdomen and not crossing over from the right to the left side. This level is too low for the duct's crossing point. Therefore, A is incorrect. (C) L1 At the L1 level, the cisterna chyli, the lower portion of the thoracic duct, is located. The duct does not cross sides at this level. It only ascends through the thoracic cavity and crosses from right to left at the level of T5. Therefore, C is incorrect. (D) L5 The L5 vertebral level is too low for the thoracic duct to cross from right to left. The thoracic duct crosses at the T5 level, much higher in the thoracic region. Therefore, D is incorrect.

questions.text: A resident physician is demonstrating the correct technique for inserting a subclavian central venous line. He has a intern palpate the clavicle, then the chest wall below it. The first bony structure that can be palpated below the inferior margin of the medial portion of the clavicle is the
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The palpable space immediately inferior to the clavicle is the first intercostal space, and the bone below it is the second rib. The acromion is the lateral extension of the scapular spine. The atlas is the first cervical vertebra, articulating with the occipital bone above and the axis below. The first rib is hidden under the clavicle.

questions.text: Left superior intercostal vein drains into
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Superior intercostal vein is formed by 2nd, 3rd and 4th posterior intercostal veins. On Right side,It drains into azygous vein. On Left side,It drains into left brachiocephalic Vein.

questions.text: Structures arranged from anterior to posterior relations in lung hilum are
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Structures arranged from anterior to posterior relations in lung hilum are VAB i.e., VEIN ,ARTERY and BRONCHUS.

questions.text: All of the following arteries supply the marked part except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The marked area in this question is Right ventricle. Option A,B,D-Marginal artery,Anterior interventricular artery and Right coronary artery all supplies the right ventricle. Option C-Diagonal artery supplies the left ventricle,not right ventricle.

questions.text: From which of the following the marked structure develops?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Subcardinal vein gives rise to gonadal vein. Option B-Marked structure is Azygous vein, which is formed by supracardinal vein. Option C-Common cardinal takes part in fromation of IVC. Option D-Anterior cardinal gives rise to internal jugular veins.

questions.text: Identify the marked Structure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Ascending aorta is located anteriorly. Option B-Pulmonary trunk divides into two pulmonary arteries, just behind ascending aorta. Option C-Oesophagus is situated just anterior to vertebral column. Option D-SVC is located on the right side and opens into right atrium.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-The subaortic curtain is part of the fibrous skeleton of the heart. It is a fibrous sheet that spans the gap between the fibrous arches supporting the right posterior and left posterior leaflets of the aortic valve. Option B-Cusp of mitral valve will be seen within right AV orifice. Option C-Cusp of Aortic valve will be seen within left AV orifice. Option D-Anterior aortic sinus is located within the initial segment of ascending aorta.
